column5: Since your on medication for bipolar and depression, drinking wouldn‚Äôt lead to anything good. Alcohol is a depressant. Take from someone who also has mental illness: drinking will feel good for a few hours but the next day (or even days) will feel like shit. The last time I drank, I had a hangover for 4 days. It wasn‚Äôt a physical hangover, it was a mental health hangover. Is it really worth risking everything you‚Äôve achieved in your sobriety to see if you can drink in moderation?

In a perfect world drinking in moderation would be great for those of us in recovery. For myself personally, there is no moderation when it comes to drinking. Its all or nothing for me. It‚Äôs a slippery slope when it comes to thinking a person can drink in moderation while in recovery. 

Let me ask this: do you think if you start drinking in moderation you‚Äôll be tempted to go back to drugs?
It‚Äôs nice of you to want to move him into your house. However, unless he decides he wants help, having him move for a fresh start won‚Äôt make much difference. Good luck! üñ§

It stems from having no true sense of self. I don‚Äôt have any advice to give you because I‚Äôm in the same boat when it comes to my schooling. I have no idea what I want to actually do with my schooling for a career. I will add that over the last few years I have figured out a few things I personally like. I say it like because I‚Äôm not liking things because others like it and I‚Äôm trying to fit in. I‚Äôm liking things because I truly like them.

I‚Äôve been diagnosed with unspecified anxiety. Along with borderline personality disorder and major depressive disorder. In a nutshell, my mental health is the reason I used to drink. Drinking always made me feel, I don‚Äôt want to say normal because I don‚Äôt believe anyone is normal, but more of something I could control. Until I couldn‚Äôt. 

I never understand how other people could drink like they do and feel pretty good the next day. I finally realized that the way I felt the next day was due to my mental health. The last time I drank, I was hung over for 4 days. It wasn‚Äôt a physical hangover, it was a mental health hang over. I realized that my mental health is too important to keep drinking. 

Now that I‚Äôm sober, my mental health has gotten much better. I completed another 6 months of DBT with my therapist telling me she was 100% fine with me completely it. With all that is going on in the world right now, my depression and anxiety have gotten a bit worse but I‚Äôm able to handle it. 

All in all my mental health is the best it‚Äôs been in 20 years. Hope this helps! üñ§

The thing with DBT is it takes work and it takes time for the skills to work. Your brain didn‚Äôt become like it is overnight and learning to use the DBT skills to retrain your brain doesn‚Äôt happen overnight. I started with DBT two years ago and I hated using the skills. I resented DBT. Now, after two years, I use the skills in my daily life. Is my life picture perfect? Hell no! I still have my bad days but the difference is now I don‚Äôt allow those bad days overwhelm me. I promise you DBT works.
Do you mind if I share this in a Facebook and give you credit for it?

To find a good therapist look at ones who specialize in DBT. They won‚Äôt have the stigma that surrounds BPD or they shouldn‚Äôt have the stigma. As for the psychiatrist, I have no good answer for that one. I‚Äôve been fortunate enough not to have any providers that judge people with BPD. I‚Äôm sorry you are experiencing that! Good luck on finding a good mental health team! üñ§

Give it a try! The first community I had dread zone well... let‚Äôs just say I only lasted 2 days before I switched back to standard zone. I‚Äôve been playing the dread zone for about two months now and standard zone seems too easy. It takes patient but it‚Äôs fun!

I‚Äôm sorry your struggling so much! It may be a combination of depression and loss of sleep causing the memory loss. From personal experience, when I don‚Äôt sleep well and my depression is bad, my memory goes to shit. Have you tried melatonin? Or maybe if you are able to, talk to your doctor about prescribing you something to sleep.

You know what you said does make sense. My face feels fine once it‚Äôs completely dry and I have moisturized it.
I use a wash cloth to rinse the cleanser off and splash my face with water afterward. I‚Äôve used cold and lukewarm water. My skin type would be dry/dehydrated. It‚Äôs mainly dehydrated in winter.

Since you said that you do wash your hair and use heat tools on it most days, I would say stay away from the tools for awhile, get some good deep conditioner and see if you get Olaplex #3 to help restore your hair. I also have thinning hair (mines due to a medicine I was on back in 2017. My hair hasn‚Äôt been the same since üòí). I have found using the Redken High Rise shampoo and conditioner gives my hair extra volume. I also use the Redken Anti-snap shampoo and conditioner. I‚Äôve been taking a biotin supplement since January. With all that, my hair seems to be finally getting back to where it was 3 years ago.
Are you on any medications that can cause hair loss? Have you had your thyroid checked?

DBT has changed my life for the better. It‚Äôs truly has been a life saver. I recently graduated from DBT with my therapist telling me she was 100% comfortable with me graduating. I won‚Äôt lie and say DBT is easy, because it isn‚Äôt. It takes a lot of hard work to change your brain and how you react to things. I still have bad days but the difference is now I do not allow those bad days to rule my life. And it‚Äôs all thanks to DBT.

Edit: I wanted to add don‚Äôt start DBT until you are ready. I fully believe that in order for DBT to work, a person has to be willing to make the change.
Thank you for your post!! The urge to drink has been bad lately. Your post reminded me what would happen if I take that drink! Hope you feel better soon! üñ§

Yup. My depression is making me feel exhausted. My anxiety is making me feel edgy and tense. Those two playing up is making the borderline personality disorder want to rear it‚Äôs ugly head. So, I‚Äôm having to be mindful of it all. I‚Äôve been doing a lot of mindfulness, self-care and being honest with the people I live with that I‚Äôm struggling (I live with my son and his dad. His dad and I are not involved in any sort of romantic relationship. I am a friend renting a room). 

I told my son that right now, my brain is a bit sadder compared to what it usually is. I made sure to let him know that once thing calm down, my brain won‚Äôt be as sad anymore.  

Sending you a big hug! üñ§

I said in my personal experience (and the people I know) I hadn‚Äôt heard of it before not that it doesn‚Äôt happen. I know that for myself, it will be awhile before I am able to stop seeing my therapist.

Hmm. That seems a little odd. I was with my old therapist for two and half years before I switched to my current therapist. I switched therapist because I wanted to start DBT (dialectical behavior therapy) and my old therapist wasn‚Äôt a DBT therapist. I‚Äôve been with my current therapist for two years now. In my personal experience I‚Äôve never heard of a therapist just terminating a patient.
Did she give you a reason why she is no longer seeing you?
Josephine is Mary‚Äôs middle name. Would it have been common back than to have two daughters with the same middle name?

As someone who has been on the side of struggling with their mental health and pulled away from my son, the best way will be to do what you are planning on doing. Having the 3 of you visit for awhile will be a good start. I would say do a minimum of 3-6 months visit with all 3 of you. Ask your son how he‚Äôs feeling after the visits. If he communicates that he‚Äôs feeling uncomfortable, don‚Äôt allow his dad to be left alone till he‚Äôs more comfortable. It‚Äôs all about what your son wants and feels comfortable with. Once he feels comfortable, telling your sons dad that he can take him for an hour or two by himself on a certain day. 

The one thing I have learned is it takes time rebuild the relationship. Granted your son is a little younger so it will be a little easier to rebuild the relationship but it will still take time. I will say that for me personally even though I am back in my sons life (I currently rent a room in his dads house. We have no romantic relationship. I am a friend renting a room.) I don‚Äôt have the confidence to be the mom he needs me to be. 

Good luck!

Edit: I wanted to add that when my son was 5 (he‚Äôs 9 now) I told him about my mental health. I explained to him that my brain is a little sadder then his and that‚Äôs the reason why I wasn‚Äôt around more.

You are shaming women if they decide not to breastfeed. Did I produce milk? Yes.  However, developing postpartum depression a week after my son was born made breastfeeding a horrible experience. So, I switched to formula so I wouldn‚Äôt be myself up more. 

Also:
[They still need formula at 8 months ](https://www.cdc.gov/nutrition/infantandtoddlernutrition/formula-feeding/how-much-how-often.html). 

[This article says the same thing. ](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/wellness-and-prevention/feeding-guide-for-the-first-year).
Some women cannot breast feed. As long as a baby is fed, have it be by breast or formula, that‚Äôs all that matters.

That a doctor isn‚Äôt going to diagnose someone having quiet BPD or a mild case of BPD. Either a person has it or doesn‚Äôt have it.

It sounds like your not fully ready to make the change. If you aren‚Äôt yet, you aren‚Äôt ready. Don‚Äôt make the change till your ready. I fully believe that if a person is pushed into DBT or start DBT (or any other types of therapy) before they are ready, they are less likely to have the skills for them. I say that because if I had started DBT before I was ready, it wouldn‚Äôt work for me. Hell, even when I started it I still had willfulness towards using the skills. But I slowly realized that the skills work and I had to do in order to achieve what I wanted. üñ§

While I don‚Äôt have a stutter I did have a speech impediment when I was younger. When I would say a word with a L or R it would sound like a W. Basically, I had to learn how to talk. There are some phrases (such as railroad) that I still fully can‚Äôt pronounce. You wouldn‚Äôt know I had a speech impediment unless I told you. I went through 6 years of speech therapy in order to learn how to talk properly. 

I never thought about passing it on to my son because it doesn‚Äôt affect my everyday life. However, I have noticed he has slight speech impediment. Nothing like I had but it‚Äôs there. When that happens, I gently correct him. 

If your kids develop a stutter, they develop a stutter. If they get teased or mocked for it, you will be the best ally for them to help because you‚Äôve been where they are. In my opinion, it makes you a better mother. 

Don‚Äôt beat yourself up over something that hasn‚Äôt happened and may not happen. üñ§

Don‚Äôt feel discourage! Even though your friend expects you to heal faster, healing isn‚Äôt linear and doesn‚Äôt happen overnight. Focus on him telling you how much you‚Äôve improved and how proud he is of you. Let him know that your brain didn‚Äôt become like it is overnight and healing your brain isn‚Äôt going to happen overnight. Even though you are still early in your healing journey, you‚Äôve already made great strides. Focus on that! I know how easy it is become discouraged but keep working at it! I have faith in you! Keep up the good work! üñ§

Right away she told me DBT would be the best option but never pushed onto me until I told her I was ready. She referred me to my current therapist who she has worked with doing a day group. I will be forever grateful for both therapist and my mental health team.

Yes I do feel better! One of the things that helped me with my interpersonal relationships is when my bestie starting setting boundaries with me. When I would lash out at her when we where talking, she started telling me ‚ÄúI‚Äôm ending this convo now. Get ahold of me when you‚Äôve calmed down, we will talk more and see if we can find a solution to what‚Äôs going on.‚Äù I resented that when she first starting doing it. Now I know why she does it and it‚Äôs helped me when I‚Äôve had to set boundaries with others in my life. 

Don‚Äôt be afraid to set boundaries with the person you know. They will hate it at first, but it will help both of you in the long run! üñ§

I‚Äôm not a doctor but from what you said, it says like she might have a fear of abandonment. Which is one of the traits of a person with BPD.
